Losing touch

Being confirmed as mentally ill was one of the least worrying moments of my life (Thumbnail credit Photo: Justyn Hardcastle)

Social pariah: Charlotte Hogarth-Jones

"So who's going in Charlotte's car?" "NOT ME!" exclaim roughly 90% of the people around me, with a haste which is little short of insulting

How the other half play

Sam Lawson investigates the sports that take place in some of Britain's most exclusive institutions. (Thumbnail credit Students play the Eton Wall Game, Image: Eton College)

So-called Life: Liam O'Brien

The advent of Freeview has increasingly meant that my life away from home is dictated by the TV schedule

Bikinis by numbers

Bikinis by numbers

MUSE: 25 May 2010

8am: Monday morning. I am listening to a rousing conversation about the differences between the way men and women talk about sex

The Acquaintance

Unsurprisingly, the heat wave has unleashed the beasts; or, to be more precise, a number of beasts with very different agendas

The Last Five Years

An emotionally compelling and musically magnificent portrayal of Jason Robert Brown's one act musical The Last Five Years with its intense exploration of the marriage of the flourishing novelist Jamie Wellerstein (Joe Hufton) to the sadly suffering actress Cathy Hyatt (Laura Horton) which was based on Brown's failed marriage to Theresa O'Neill. (Thumbnail credit Faye Tyreman)

Henry Moore, Tate Britain

Having recently completed a History of Art module with Moore at its nucleus, a trip to this exhibition was, I'll admit, less of an indifferent jaunt and more of a necessity for me. Yet while your reviewer is by no means an impartial observer, I will try to keep an open mind (Thumbnail credit Tube Shelter Perspective Liverpool Street Extension 1941, Tate (c) Reproduced by permission of The Henry Moore Foundation)

A Passion for Crime: An interview with Peter James

By James Bithell

The average reading age of a prison inmate is just 9 years old (Thumbnail credit Peter James)

Spring Awakening

Spring Awakening, written by Frank Wedekind, is a challenging and sophisticated play, potentially difficult to get right

Book, line and sinker: The literary revival that's reeled us in

Gok Wan, the cast of Wicked, and the York English department; what could they possibly have in common?

Hard to Beat

By James Bithell

The 'All Tomorrow's Parties' series has become notorious - a crazy diamond in the crown of British festivals

Four Lions

The first time I heard about Chris Morris' new film, it was undergoing some serious scrutiny on the radio

Norman Rea Gallery's Light Themed Summer Show

This year the Norman Rea Gallery will be launching their summer programme with an Academy Style Summer show opening Monday week 4, May 17th

Lorca is dead: or a Brief History of Surrealism

1. There are no wrong answers

Elysium

Elysium, a resoundingly successful modern musical adaptation of William Shakespeare's 'Twelfth Night' by University of York student Mark Perkins, played this weekend in Sir Jack Lyons Concert Hall as his final year music project

Foundings and Fledglings

Following a long tradition of artists active in supporting The Foundling hospital, this year three renowned contemporary artists joined the canon of greats, showing work alongside masters like Hogarth in and around the museum (Thumbnail credit Foundlings and Fledglings - Our Angels of this Earth, 2009, argon, by Tracey Emin, courtesy of White Cube, photo Benjamin Westoby)

Frida and Diego

Frida and Diego, a love story by Greg Cullen, centres on the meeting and romance of two of Mexico's most influential and controversial artists, Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera (Thumbnail credit Frida Kahlo copyright Nikolas Muray)

Thirteen Thirty One

Certainly, tread very carefully when entering an establishment that peddles food by day and drunkenness by night

The Courtyard

Inspired by the elections last term, I decided it was time to take a stand. I launched my own one-man guerrilla campaign on the YUSU suggestion box. I was going to get pancakes on the menu if it killed me

Pub

First things first, York's Hole in the Wall has nothing to do with that ghastly Saturday night TV show, and the Petergate pub doesn't need silver lycra to draw a crowd

Michael Allard

An <em>Anchorman<em> sequel is on the horizon, and, well, it's kind of a big deal

Centurion

It seems that filmmakers are never afraid to tackle and (for want of a better word) copy exactly the same subject matter as another film made in the same year. Such is the case with Kevin Macdonald's The Eagle Of The Ninth, released later this year, in the wake of Centurion, Neil Marshall's latest offering

The Front

In his most celebrated work, Woody Allen is both an amateur and an actor playing variations on the creative persona that's still going strong after 50 years onscreen

Cemetery Junction

It seems reasonable to assume that the vast majority of Cemetery Junction's audience will choose to watch the film based solely on Ricky Gervais and Stephen Merchant's sterling comic partnership, whose reputation was cemented by the stratospheric success of The Office and Extras

Intrepid indie ecologists Stornoway

UK indie has had many past dalliances with the pastoral; most recently British Sea Power with their foliage obsession and appearance on Countryfile. But Stornoway's sound - whimsical pop-folk that suggests sun-dappled meadows and rolling dales - is backed up with professional experience in ecology (Thumbnail credit Stornoway enjoying a post-hike sing-song)

Future Sounds

If we haven't rubbed it in your face enough yet, this weekend was 'Live at Leeds'

True Sounds of Liberty

Hannah Ellis-Petersen talks to the only boys wearing drainpipes in Kabul

Paloma Faith

aloma Faith's star is soaring. Following memorable performances on 'Later... with Jools Holland' and the considerable vitriol aimed at her outrageous outfits in Heat magazine, Faith is closing her first headlining tour in London
